Poland, like many other European countries, is fully enjoying its youth as a new and incredibly enthusiastic craft beer country - and with the advent of young and enthusiastic craft breweries and equally enthusiastic domestic (and increasingly foreign) followings, come the hypes. This bourbon barrel aged Â’impyÂ’ is one of those new Polish hypes, so IÂ’m curious to find out what this is all about. IÂ’m rating the 2016 edition at 11.5% ABV. Thin, yellowish beige, creamy head, immediately reduced to a tan ring around the glass and a few dots in the middle, but in that form retaining very well, over a pitch black beer with reddish burgundy edges of about two millimeters Â’deepÂ’. Strong, complex and Â’matureÂ’ bouquet of inevitable bourbon, piercing brightly through a thick mass of unsugared black chocolate, cold espresso, dried prunes, old furniture woodiness, old raisins, wet leather, chewing tobacco, shoe polish, rum, dry madera, black cherries, vanilla-ish oak, cinnamon rolls, burnt toast, wood glue, venison stock, black peppercorns, clotted blood, dried elderberries. Intense onset, concentrated candied sweetness (raisin, dried plum) immediately surrounded by a deep sourishness of roasted barley on the one hand and a thick edge of Â’meatyÂ’, beef stock-like umami; soft carbo, very thick and viscous, thickly oily mouthfeel. An ominous mass of blackness ensues, with thoroughly nutty (as in roasted walnuts), bitter black chocolate- and burnt-toast-like malt flavors completely filling the mouth cavity, acquiring ever more roasted bitterness, to an old charred coffee bean-like degree; meanwhile, a kind of thin Â’ironÂ’-like sensation sits at the edges, but nothing industrial, more like the taste of blood if I may put it like that... Intense, rich and heart-warming finish, tons of black maltiness and roasted barley with that conspicuous Â’blood tasteÂ’ alongside, all dried by a peppery hop punch and, more than anything else of course, a lot of tannic woodiness, almost old wooden board-like, eventually drenched in bourbon - the bittersweet flavor of which actually seems to soften the roasted bitterness of the malts a bit in this particular case. The alcohol in the end is firm, evidently bourbon- but also very rum-like and heats the throat. This is an intense beer for sure, very clearly inspired by the great American barrel aged stouts, the names made legendary by two decades of Â’beer geekismÂ’ as it were - not such an easy task to come up with something of that level of quality, intensity and boldness, but these guys clearly pulled it off. It is very apparent that no compromises were made here - this stout is at a par with the great barrel aged stouts of De Molen in the Netherlands, for example, with which I find certain similarities as well as with the aforementioned famous American BBA stouts. This is not the first time this new generation of Polish craft brewers astonishes me - IÂ’d say their enthusiasm (see e.g. the countless Polish ratings on this site) is justified. World class stout!
